explanation:
For a sound dead-code (MISRA) analysis of calculate_add_nonce_with_retry we must know all symbols that affect whether any executed operation can be removed without changing program behaviour. Brief reasons why each symbol is required:

- calculate_add_nonce: The primary callee whose success/failure decides whether the retry path (including many operations) is executed; also has side effects (nonce registration) that affect later behaviour.
- digest_ext_error: When defined and true it causes an immediate return (no retry). Its presence/behaviour can make the retry code dead or live.
- digest_reset: Called before the second calculate_add_nonce; may have side effects required for a meaningful retry — if it is a no-op the call could be dead.
- digest_get_size: Determines digest_size used for buffer sizing and the length passed to memcpy; affects whether memory operations are meaningful.
- calculate_nonce, get_nonce_nc_idx, is_slot_available: Internal helpers used by calculate_add_nonce; their logic determines why calculate_add_nonce may fail (e.g. slot collisions, availability) and so whether retry code is ever needed.
- MHD_monotonic_msec_counter: Produces timestamp1 and timestamp2; equality/variance of these values controls whether the timestamp-differentiation/randomisation path runs.
- MHD_get_master and its fields digest_auth_rand_size, nonce_nc_size: digest_auth_rand_size controls whether the DLOG is invoked; nonce_nc_size==0 disables retries entirely. Knowledge of the master struct and these fields is required to decide if the logging or retry branches are dead.
- MHD_DLOG: Logging call — although seemingly only a diagnostic, its removal may change observable behaviour (logging), so its implementation/semantics should be known to decide if it is removable.
- HAVE_MESSAGES, MHD_DIGEST_HAS_EXT_ERROR, HAVE_RANDOM, HAVE_RAND: Preprocessor configuration macros that enable/disable blocks of code; whether those flags are set will directly alter which operations exist in the compiled binary (i.e. whether code is present/absent or dead).
- random, rand: If one of these is used in the compiled build they produce the non-deterministic bases for timestamp adjustment; their presence/absence changes which instructions execute.
- _MHD_ROTL32, _MHD_ROTR32, __builtin_rotateleft32: The rotate operations used in the weak pseudo-random transformation; must know they are pure transforms (no side effects) to decide if their calls could be removed.
- NONCE_STD_LEN, MAX_DIGEST: Macros used to size nonce2 and to determine copy length — required to know buffer usage and whether memcpy is meaningful.
- DAUTH_JUMPBACK_MAX: Limits how much timestamp2 is adjusted; influences timestamp arithmetic and whether the adjustment logic is relevant.
- mhd_assert: Assertion may be compiled out or abort on failure; its presence/behaviour affects whether the mhd_assert call is observable/removable.

Providing these symbols (implementations, definitions or configuration values) lets the next analyst determine which branches/operations are genuinely executed and whether removing any of them would change program behaviour (i.e. if they are dead code).
